title: USD Coin Sorter (Quarters, Dimes, Nickels, Pennies) for .5mm nozzle

description.text:
Remixed from this auto coin sorter

I edited the OpenSCAD file to change the nozzle size from .4 to .5 and the coin arrays to just support the main four USD coins (Pennies, Nickels, Dimes, Quarters)

I tried to print KeelinJ's remix but the back of the basebox didn't print since my nozzle is a little bigger than the Ultimaker

Instructions for use
To store a coin, you may release a coin from the rightmost top, and it will slide down the hill and go into the right tube. To get a coin, you may pull the whole rack out and take out any coin.

Printing (copied from youngkat's instructions)
These instructions below are especially for Ultimaker2 printer and Cura software. Please adjust any parameter as needed if you are using other software.

  1. Use 'normal' quality. Or if you're an expert, consider using the settings provided below.
  2. Print the top board
    • Cura expert settings:
    • Layer height = 0.1mm,
    • Shell thickness = 2.4mm,
    • Bottom/top thickness = 1.5mm.
    • Print!
  3. Print the base box
    • Cura expert settings:
    • Layer height = 0.1mm,
    • Shell thickness = Bottom/top thickness = 1.2mm.
    • Tune retraction settings at the printer:
    • Retraction length = 3mm.
    • Print!
  4. Print the tubes. Same settings as step 3.
    • Put them together. Done!

Monoprice Maker Select 3d

Enrico.

The model is called ProteggiPulegge and serves to prevent the small material may be present on the printing plate (such as residues from previous prints , or pieces of filament or dried glue or other) can finish on engine pulleys and wedged between these and related belts , inevitably causing printing errors .

Much more coming soon in the MOKO Mini Pulley system... ???????? Just add string & imagination for untold possibilities!
Turn off the light, open curtains, close & open doors, retrieve snacks, suspend valuables, hang clothes, tease cats, all without leaving your bed! Snap together body with locking clips- no pins or tools required Quickly & easily locks to common screws or nails Liberate the lazy Luddite within! Tech specs on the Instructions page
Assembly & demonstration video: http://youtu.be/rfS4dhbxeSY ???????? New attachment added: Pulley Hook
The hook fits snugly in the screw cavity in both the MOKO Mini Pulley & the Mini Block & Tackle Pulley. Break the hook pin at the snap points to shorten if required New attachment added: Pulley Magnet
Snugly holds 8x5mm Neodymium Disc Magnets (ebay) Use in conjunction with the Pulley Hook to fish for metallic treasures!

I've made the MOKO Mini Pulley with both locking (closed) or quick release (open) fittings  
Printed in .20mm layers on my UP! printer, however the design is quite forgiving and adaptable. The locking clips can be replaced with cable ties or rubber bands  
The quick release design locks to countersunk/bugle screw/nails up to 8.2mm (.32") head diameter  
Takes rope/cord/twine/string up to 4mm diameter, Load tested to 5kg  
DIY Rube Goldberg machine, or perhaps a lightswitch remote control? Home automation, garden adventures, tricks or traps... add a fishing reel as a mini-winch. Share your creations!

title: DE3P2S Double Edge Razor Altoids Insert

description.text:
So this isn't entirely original work, because the inspiration for this was taken from ShaveStash at the following: https://www.etsy.com/listing/182665300/shave-stash-custom-travel-case-for-a-de

I did, however, CAD it from the ground up, so I guess there's something original in here. Anyways, this insert fits the large Altoids tin and I store my DE3P2S double edge razor from Stirling Razor in here for travelling. It fits 5 blades quite well, but with some forcing, I can get 7 blades in the slot.

UPDATE: So it looks like Stirling Soap actually had some minor changes to the DE3P2S razor that they offer. The first one I had (ordered 12/8/16) has a slightly shorter handle and blade registration pegs that protrude farther through the bottom of the head. The updated one (received 1/4/17) has a slightly longer handle. The blade registration pegs of the head are also shorter and don't stick out the bottom.

Some of the side walls also now have draft angles to make the razor parts easier to take out.

description.text: When you built your Eggbot ( http://egg-bot.com ), were you disappointed that the default pen arm wasn't large enough to accept the ubiquitous fine point Sharpie marker? I know I was (especially since I had just bought a pack specifically for my new Eggbot). This model is a replacement pen arm for the Eggbot, designed to accept Sharpie fine point markers (of course, anything smaller in diameter will fit too!).

I printed with a Maker Bot TOM (with ABP) with the following settings: 1.75 mm ABS plastic
.4 mm extruder diameter
Extruder temp of 125
No raft
Platform temp of 120 C (important for ensuring that the print doesn't curl when using the ABP)
3 shells (may want to bump it up to 4, if you like)
*15% fill
.3 mm layer height After printing, I'd recommend putting in the screws first, then removing them to "thread" the holes, before you fasten it to your Eggbot (it takes a little elbow grease as the holes in the model are smaller than the screws to ensure a firm grip). Then remove the nut from your default Eggbot pen arm and insert it into this new arm. Put in the thumbscrew, a marker, and you're good to go.

comments.text: The Eggbot product page explicitly states that it fits Sharpie Ultra Fine Point pens.  There are also pen arms available for the wider "fine" point Sharpies.  I don't think that you should be "disappointed" just because you didn't read the product page.  :(
comments.author: oskay

comments.text: I read the product page, but I was hoping that the default pen arm would fit the fine point with perhaps a little effort.  The difference between the fine and the ultra fine is about a millimeter, so I thought it just might fit.
comments.author: oskay

Originally designed so that players in tabletop RPGs could keep track of how many bullets they had left before they needed to reload, this can also be used for cosplay or a awesome decoration. Designed to fit two standard skateboard bearings (also the ones used in Lulzbot printers) so that you could have it on a stand and spin it, possibly for a non-dangerous game of Russian Roulette or something similar.

This would also make a badass elaborate spinning beltbuckle, if y'all are feelin' like doin' a remix.

This was not intended nor scaled for actual bullets, DO NOT USE THIS IN A ACTUAL GUN. The is purely a prop.

Enjoy!

Getting the Model

This is a 3D scan from ~40 images stitched together by Autodesk's Recap360.
The model created by Autodesk required much post-processing using MeshMixer.
.OBJ should have the texture data attached

I found that Autodesk Recap360:
~ Didn't like pictures taken of objects on lazy-susans where the background stays the same
~ Stitched the images together better if they were in Black & White instead of full color
~ It made things easier to manually stitch the images together if there were markers on the object, in this case face painting and hair accessories (and facial blemishes >_< )

description.text:
This is still a work in progress!

The idea is to make a walking aid for persons who have some motor controls but not enough strength to actually walk. The motors would amplify their intended movement allowing greater mobility.

There's and SWF Video of the motors moving in "thing files" (download) section.

I thought I'd share to see if the open source community would assist, I'd welcome constructive feedback, ideas etc.

NB: -- In spite of my username, I'm not a doctor and have no medical training whatsoever! I can't say this work is fit for any purpose other than research.

The STL files are Joints and linkages for 20X20 Bosch Rexroth aluminium extrusion.
Used with GLA750 Linear Actuators (run at 18V DC) and a Mystic 'seat type' kite surfing harness.
I got my 50 mm actuators here: https://gimsonrobotics.co.uk/categories/linear-actuators/products/gla750-12v-dc-small-linear-actuator

I used both plastic (M8 Male) and metal (M6 Male) rod end bearings available from RS Online:
http://ie.rs-online.com/web/c/pneumatics-hydraulics-power-transmission/power-transmission-rod-ends-spherical-bearings/rod-ends/?searchTerm=rod+end
and a good many bearings, bushings and bolts "recycled" from an old pair of roller skates.

Leg supports also house switches or other sensors to tell the (optional) Arduino or stand-alone controllers when to drive the motors and when to stop.

There are various control options:

  1. Dual DC Motor drivers - with or without Joystick control / with or without Arduino.

  2. An Arduino and a couple of solid state relay boards (dual H Bridge) to drive the motors at 18V.

Update: 16 Sept 2016 - I got some new controllers to try out. So far, the "Cytron 10A 5-25V Dual Channel DC Motor Drivers" that I got from: http://www.robotshop.com/eu/en/10a-5-30v-dual-channel-dc-motor-driver.html
look very promising indeed. (Control option 1)

They come with inbuilt "test" buttons - forward and backwards for each of the 2 motor channels.
These can be wired directly to the switches on the legs meaning there's no requirement for Arduino, coding etc.
However they can be interfaced to Arduino for more advanced control options if desired.
They also support joystick control - out of the box!

Two would be required (one for each leg) but there's a pleasing simplicity to this layout and certain protections are built in to the controller board. Testing is ongoing but so far - I'm very happy with them.

Dual H Bridges (Control option 2)
http://mg.elecrow.com/arduino-compatible/shield.html
http://www.homotix.eu/product.php~idx~~~586~~locale~~~225~~Dual+Channel+H_Bridge+Motor+Shield+_8A+22V~.html
I smoked my Elecrows while working on the Arduino code - Not certain why, the code looked ok and connections were correct.
I guess the "pull down" resistors I used; that should have held one pin low while the other was high were poorly selected, allowing high on both pins.
My own fault.

Choose your own batteries - I'm using 18v Ni-Cd 'battery drill' batteries (Makita) for the testing - there's probably better choices for endurance and performance etc but they're ok for what I'm doing now.

The 20X20 aluminium extrusion provides multiple attachment points for linkages, batteries cover panels/enclosures etc. It is strong / lightweight and readily available.

Thigh Support files uploaded. - You may need to print them at 95% scale as the thigh support is right on printer limits for size (200X200X200). If you have a square print bed - place them on the bed at 45 degree angle to maximise the print size.

Note - All Leg supports are best printed at 100% Infill.

Added a general purpose strap attachment point for the harness - for additional supports, back brace etc. Can be attached where needed in your particular situation. Straps could be used from the hip motor mount, crossing at the chest and attaching to this clip at the mid point (top) of the back of the harness.

The Arduino code is very raw, it was just to get the motors moving. (For control option 2)
You'll need the excellent driver that was created by Christoph Bober in order to use the .ino file - you'll find it on his site here:
http://www.christophbober.com/?p=70
(I just put the .h and the .cpp file in the same directory as the .ino but I believe there are more elegant ways to do it.)
Currently - only 2 switches are controlling 2 motors. There really needs to be 4 switch inputs. It's just an opening shot. Coding doesn't come naturally to me so I'm feeling my way.

Update: 22 August 2016 - I started writing a build steps manual - I've uploaded a PDF of the build steps document at it's current state of completion. Further updates expected.

At the moment I have no motorisation or damper for the ankle (I'll try printing a damper to see how it works) and rotation of the thigh (for turning) is limited.

An additional stiffener support is needed between the Hip_Harness_Attchmt and the Hip_Motor_Mount. I'm planning to use a section of aluminium extrusion to ensure the hip motor movement transfers to the leg rather than causing the harness to crumple.

Feel free to use this as a starting point - if you want to implement voice control from a smartphone or inertial referencing - I won't try to stop you :o)

I re-used some things I found on Thingiverse - modified them etc. If you deserve credit for any work here please let me know.

Printer:

K8200

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20 - 25%

Notes:

Printed everything in Bridge Nylon - mechanical properties of other materials were not satisfactory in my mind. Some files have supports built in, they can be easily cut off with scissors or a sharp bladed cutting tool.
Cut away supports with scissors.
Lots of trial and error - on a shoe-string budget as a spare time project.

Another option would be to mount both motors on the thigh.

Both using the same (modified) mount and facing in opposite directions. That way; there would be less bulk on the hip and no need for additional support on the harness (to avoid crumple). Implementing the ability to turn is the challenge in that arrangement but it would be a cleaner design.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with Inland 1.75mm PETG (translucent magenta).  I used 0.1mm layer height, but that really isn't necessary on this part.  I used my default profile, which includes a lot of top and bottom layers.  I didn't use a very high infill percentage.  You could use almost any settings as long as the part ends up rigid.  You could probably use almost any printing material - but I have had bad luck with PLA for motor mounts, so I probably wouldn't recommend that.  I specifically designed this to make it easy to print (no bridges, no overhangs, no need for support, no need for a raft) - so there shouldn't be a lot of issues.  It is a little large, so there could be issues with warping depending on filament and settings.
print_settings.Infill:: high enough to make the part stiff

description.text:
This is a part to mount an E3D Titan Extruder to a Misumi aluminum extrusion. I made this specifically for my custom-built printer, but it occurred to me that this sort of mounting need might not be uncommon. I have included the OpenSCAD file for the part and have made almost everything a parameter that you can edit at will.

I do not have this in place yet, but expect to remove the old extruder and install the new Titan within the next couple of days. I will include additional pictures as I do so.

Update 2 - 20160501 - Alright, the problem mentioned in Update 1 is fixed now. I have printed the current version and installed it successfully on my printer. It seems to work fine. I still need to dial in the new extruder, but that has nothing to do with the mount.

The mount works pretty well. It is very rigid, very easy to print, and holds the extruder as desired. Orientations on my system makes the extruder not as accessible as might be desired. The manual feed gear is in back and next to the extrusion - not so easy to turn by hand. There is now a good 2mm clearance for that gear, it just isn't that easy to get to. Similarly, the see through face is inconveniently facing an area that is hard to get to. That is mostly the geometry of my system. That said, the extruder seems to work well at least in the feeding I have done so far. It might be better if the extruder was mounted at the side of the beam rather than even with it... Maybe something for a future change.

Update 1 - 20160430 - Hold off on printing this for right now. I tried to put it in place, but found that the orientation needed for a bowden setup puts the acetyl gear next to the mounting beam. There is not enough separation to allow it to fit. I will have to play with the values a bit to make room. Should be an easy fix, but I don't yet know the correct separation to make it work.

I printed this with Inland 1.75mm PETG (translucent magenta). I used 0.1mm layer height, but that really isn't necessary on this part. I used my default profile, which includes a lot of top and bottom layers. I didn't use a very high infill percentage. You could use almost any settings as long as the part ends up rigid. You could probably use almost any printing material - but I have had bad luck with PLA for motor mounts, so I probably wouldn't recommend that. I specifically designed this to make it easy to print (no bridges, no overhangs, no need for support, no need for a raft) - so there shouldn't be a lot of issues. It is a little large, so there could be issues with warping depending on filament and settings.

after sniffing about for a bed leveling gauge design for my printer (the manufacturer supplied calibration technique is erm.....less than exacting to say the least) I couldn't find any I was happy with, some were just not usable, others were simply over engineered for purpose so I designed and made my own using the same "digital tyre gauge" that seem popular with other similar designs.

gauge is good for 1/100th of a millimeter and works very well with my design, has my bed printing bottom layers with a smoothness that puts a babies arse to shame.

two part design, supportless simple print, no bells or whistles required, just buy the 4 quid "tyre gauge" bolt it in place without modification and with some 2mm bolts and presto your away..... simples

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Warthog is basically a flying machine gun. Nonetheless the construction with 2 jet engines over the wings and the split tail unit give this plane a unique and interesting look.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. Glued together and nicely sanded it's a great toy for boys (of different age).
A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen/Flugzeugmodelle for more plane models.

Keep in mind, that the obj-file of the model is just for validating the construction and viewing in the browser.

I took 3-view drawings of this plane from wikipedia to save the tracing, then used Illustrator to carve out the main features. The slots were a result of trail and error. Before building the plane I did a 3D validation in SketchUp. Then I nested the parts as close as possible for production on a cnc-router.

My cheap surround sound system has small speakers that will hang on a screw with a keyhole.
This is a simple hook to allow a screw mount without damaging the headboard of my bed.
It's sized for a 6-32 screw to self tap into the plastic. Be careful it doesn't stick out the back and scratch the headboard.
If I had really been on the ball, I'd have added a groove to hide the wire. Too late, it's already on the printer!
(If your young, it may be a good idea to make it stronger.)

Print, insert short screw and hang.
Collect kudos from wife.

title: Eggholder 5-point
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This 5-point eggholder looks like a remix of the 4-point eggholder, but the construction is less robust. Though it has 5 legs, the constriction takes less space on the material.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1 mm flute. A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

I used Solid Edge 2D drafting which is a parametric CAD-system. It is free for personal use and – if you understand the principals of parametric design – pretty straight forward. As you can see the design is based on basic shapes. The size was determined by the size of a standard-sized egg.

description.text:
DISCLAIMER

I am no medical professional - this is just me making a thing to pursue a goal. Use this print out at your own risk!!! If something hurts or doesn't feel right STOP USING IT

Summary

Well here it is, my custom foreskin stretching restoration device. I do recommend customizing the models to fit your needs. This is based off the DTR model and the work of http://www.thingiverse.com/Syrus54/

Please review the Post-Printing directions for assembly information.

This is a work in progress please let me know any problems you have and I'll be glad to try and correct them in the source files.

Using the Device

  • Slide the "Sliding Retainer Plate" to the "Push Plate" and set in place with the set-screw. Press it down firmly on the corona and roll the loose skin over the "Sliding Retainer Plate" and secure it under the baby bottle nipple.

  • Attach a rubber band to the top posts of the hollow rod through the loops on the "Sliding Retainer Plate" and back to the other top post of the hollow rod.

  • Carefully unscrew the set-screw and allow the tension from the rubber bands to pull your foreskin slowly stretching it.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm layers

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I generally print the hollow rod on it's side with supports but everything else can be printed without them. For best results and comfort I recommend coating the two plates (pushing plate and sliding retainer plate) with tool-dip or another type of smoothing agent.

Printed in Black PLA @ 210C Extruder / 75C Bed Temp

In addition to this print you need
  • Glue (super glue or two part epoxy)
  • M3/.50 nut and M3/.50/12mm screw
  • Baby bottle nipple cut to fit
  • (Optional) Tool Dip
Tool Dip Parts (Optional)

After printing I normally give several cotes of ToolDip to both the "Push Plate" And the "Sliding Retainer Plate." This smooths out the layers and provides a bit of extra comfort but this step is optional.

Complete the Sliding Retainer Plate
  • Add the M3 nut into the Slider plate's receiving hole and glue in place.
  • Carefully stretch the baby bottle nipple over the top and trim away the excess.
Put the parts together

Slide the "Sliding Retainer Plate" onto the "Hollow Rod" and then slide the end of the "Hollow Rod" into the "Push Plate" and glue in place. The Sliding retainer plate should be able to move freely up and down the rod while the "Push Plate" stays fixed.

Use

  • Slide the "Sliding Retainer Plate" to the "Push Plate" and set in place with the set-screw. Press it down firmly on the corona and roll the loose skin over the "Sliding Retainer Plate" and secure it under the baby bottle nipple.

  • Attach a rubber band to the top posts of the hollow rod through the loops on the "Sliding Retainer Plate" and back to the other top post of the hollow rod.

  • Carefully unscrew the set-screw and allow the tension from the rubber bands to pull your foreskin slowly stretching it.

Initial models were done in tinker-cad - latest revisions come from Autodesk Fusion 360.
Based off the DTR model and the work of http://www.thingiverse.com/Syrus54/

description.text: There are two parts to this print, and it is meant to be printed with dual extruders.    I have included a file that has both, but it only prints in one color :(

Experience the unparalleled luxury of inhaling the cool smooth vapors of your finest herbs from a beautifully robot-crafted water pipe. Shaped like everyone's favorite fruit, this pipe is like nothing else that has ever been created by humankind, before or since.

The Pineapple Bubbler can be configured in a number of different ways, from a small, discreet piece to a big, long party pipe. The modular pieces can be printed in different colors, creating a smorgasbord of possibilities.

I must point out that this is to be used with a glass bowl that you must provide. You obviously cannot smoke directly out of plastic or it would melt and create toxic fumes. I recommend printing the parts from one of the various food-grade 3D printing filaments now available.

Supplies:

There are just a few things you will need to assemble your bubbler:

  • 1 #89 O-ring - http://www.amazon.com/Danco-O-Ring-Nitrile-Butadiene-Polybag/dp/B000RY9E3I/ref=sr_1_2?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1457909607&sr=1-2&keywords=%2389+o+ring+danco
  • 2 or more #17 O-ring - http://www.amazon.com/O-Ring-Nitrile-Butadiene-Rubber-Polybag/dp/B000UEX2WE/ref=sr_1_1?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1457909673&sr=1-1&keywords=%2317+o+ring+danco
  • Glass 14mm bowl - something like this http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00T9UY8W8?psc=1

Printed Parts

(print in this order):

1 Pineapple "Bulb"

  • This part must be waterproof. After much experimentation, we have found that a PLA part with 6 or more shells is sufficient to not leak, even after a few days. However, if accidentally left that way it will slowly start to take on water and develop a grungy appearance. To prevent this we are printing them more and more from PETG now.
  • This will require somewhere in the neighborhood of 100 to 200 grams of plastic, and be an overnight to full day print. depending on your settings. We've found that lots of infill doesn't do as much for moisture resistance, but lots of shells does. In ABS, you could vapor bathe it to make it water tight. ymmv.
  • You can get away with 2 or 3 shells if you only put ice in it and dump it when it starts to melt.
  • That all being said, its best to avoid leaving water in them longer than necessary.
  • You are also encouraged to decorate and waterproof your pineapple with paint, epoxy, nail polish, acrylic, or polyurethane.
  • No supports needed.

1 Pineapple Stem

  • This will require around 60 grams of plastic, and although it may not look like it will need it, use supports. It needs support for the underside of the lip, not for the leaves. It won't take much, but it will allow it to seat the o-ring so that it gets a really good seal with the bulb.
  • Once the bulb and the stem are printed, the pineapple is useable, while you wait for the other parts to print. You just need a standard glass 14mm bowl. Cover the carb with your finger for now.
  • The Bowl may be loose. This is by design, to allow for variations in the diameter. Wrap it with a few layers of tape to get a good seal and provide insulation in case the bowl ever gets too warm.

1 Mouthpiece

  • Print one to go on the end of the stem.
  • Optional Curved Mouthpiece - use this in place of the regular mouthpiece for more ergonomic pipes. Creates extra length so no stem extensions are required.

1 Carb Plug

  • A plug for the carb, featuring the Everyday Pineapple logo.

1-? Stem Extensions

  • Stem extensions add length to the stem, making it more ergonomic. You can use none at all, for a more compact device, or as many as you like, as long as you've got a friend who can reach the other end to light it.
  • We've also provided a twisty stem piece, one surrounded by the Everyday Pineapple logo, and one surrounded by a leaf emblem that can be mixed and matched, or easily customized however you want.

0-2 Ash Catcher / Pre-Cooler

  • This part is totally optional. It gives you an extra level of pre-filtration through water before the air enters the main chamber. It looks really cool, and can potentially be daisy chained two or three times if you wanna get really crazy.
  • We recommend waterproofing this one as well.

Early Adopters

Be one of the first to try out the Pineapple! We are confident that this is already the best 3D printed water pipe that has ever existed, but we welcome all feedback. What do you like about the Pineapple? What could be better? How much would you pay for one of these? What about if it was customized with your name or logo? What added features would you like to see?

Whatever you you do, please post pictures of your prints. It makes me the happiest pineapple in the world.

Our team of Oompa Loompas utilized the pineapple design from the Microsoft store to create the main parts. We took the locking mechanism from the Pill Pill Bottle and modified it to accept an o-ring. We pulled the leaf emblem from Gatewood's keychain and used that to make the stem middle piece with leaves around it. These designs all use creative commons attribution licences. We designed everything else with Tinkercad and did some final detail work with Meshmixer.

We have spent months here at Everyday Pineapple meticulously perfecting this design through many iterations. Testing each one and constantly improving upon it. I hope you enjoy it as much as we do.

The bulb is designed with an integrated down tube with diffusion holes, as you can see here:

Top down view of the bulb. This beautiful specimen is printed with woodfill

The water pipe is modular, allowing for varying configurations. The parts connect tightly with a three way locking mechanism, which is kept water and air tight with rubber o-rings.

Close up of the stem-to-bulb locking mechanism. Note the o-ring channel along the top edge. Close up of the stem-to-stem mechanism. You can see the groove for the o-ring along the bottom.

FAQ

Q: What is this?
A: This is a water pipe shaped somewhat like a pineapple. Usable for smoking any fine herbs procurable in your jurisdiction.

Q: Are these for sale?
A: Our OpenBazaar shop is now online @EverydayPineapple
9425164ff59220c90cbf5df320f4bac2d519cfe3

  • OpenBazaar is a peer to peer marketplace, powered by Bitcoin. If you'd like to purchase one through more traditional means, you can still contact us through email and twitter.

Q: Can this be used as a "dab rig"?
A: Probably, bearing a couple of things in mind. You want a rig to be small, so skip the stem extensions. You will need a glass male to male adapter, on which to mount the nail.

Q: Can I see more pictures?
A: Yes, here http://imgur.com/a/iixKA

Q: Will the Pineapple Bubbler cure what ails me?
A: Yes*

• This device has not been tested by the FDA, and is not intended to treat, cure, or prevent any disease.
  • For tobacco use only in the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Oklahoma, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, and Wyoming.

print_settings.Notes:: The cover_mobius is a tricky print. It will require a brim, and 1.5mm supports. It's best to print with a .42mm print width and .2mm layer height. I include a breakaway section at the bottom to reduce support requirements and provide a good connection to the brim. But you will need supports between the breakaway section and the cover perimeter as there is a .8mm space. So the supports should have a 1 layer gap top and bottom in this space.

description.text:
This is a replacement for the OEM Y-axis bracket for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 and clones (Monoprice, etc). The Y-axis pulley flex as the Y carriage moves back and forth and I'm not a fan of the zip-tie solution.

This bracket is rock solid and I have seen no flexing.

NOTE: This thing requires drilling.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Required:

Printed parts:
2x spacers
1x drill template
1x bracket

Hardware:
1x M5 35mm
1x M5 nylock nut
6x M3 10mm
6x M3 nylock nut

Remove the 3xM3 allen bolts keeping the OEM bracket to the printer frame.

Bolt the drill template to the outside of the printer matching the 3 holes on the left.

Make sure the bracket is level and mark the 3 holes on the right with a pencil.

Remove the drill template (or you can drill with it in place - does not make a difference).

Drill the holes.

Fit the assembled bracket (using the OEM pulley) to the inside and bolt to the frame.

Refit the belt.

Tension the belt.

Link to the public object in TinkerCad for anyone that wants to remix it:

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/67F2uTUVvB5-wanhao-duplicator-i3-y-axis-pulley

comments.text: Thank you amkza for making this, it is very much appreciated great improvement over factory original bracket, was very easy to fit using your template for the holes.

comments.text: The M5 rod I use is threaded all the way through. comments.author: amkza

comments.text: Another thought, use a DIN 931 M5 bolt, 40mm long.  The spec says this should have a 24mm unthreaded rod, with 16mm threaded at the tip.  So the bolt going through the Thing, the spacers, and the pulley is a nice solid rod, and the thread is purely for the nut (then probably need to cut about 10mm thread off for neatness!)
comments.author: atreder

comments.text:
Am about to try my second print in "Amazing Asphalt", a PET with 20% added Carbon Fibre. My first pass got a terribly clogged nozzle (this stuff behaves like asphalt!) but that which printed is as rigid as steel... Will post a pic if I succeed!
I will add my "improvement" by using a 5mm steel rod, secured with starlock washers rather than 5mm bolt. Just better engineering but probably 0% actual improvement...
As for the Y Axis motor mount, here's a thought. All the tension of the Y Axis belt creates force on the Y Axis motor bearings. I.e. those bearing end up doing 2 jobs, allowing the motor shaft to rotate and taking up the Y Axis belt tension. Ideal solution? A variant of this plate (deeper) with bearings in the frame, carrying the drive pulley (which you would adjust where it sits under the carriage), and the motor connected to the drive through a coupler, similar to the Z Drive...
Basically, take this "thing", and couple it to a variant of "Thing:985629"...
comments.author: atreder

description.text:
This is a leg extension that I created for a Room & Board Parsons cocktail table.

We bought the table in conjunction with a new couch, and found that the table was just a few inches lower than we wanted. A few hours with the 3D printer later, and voila -- the table is the right height.

To use this, simply pop off the plastic caps that are on the end of the legs of the cocktail table, print these, and slide these on. No adhesive necessary!

print_settings.Notes:: Print the plug with supports so it doesn't screw up the overhangs. The cup holder doesn't need them. I suggest an infill of 25%, but that and the resolution are up to you.

description.text:
I drive a 1987 Porsche 924S. I have two problems with the car: first, the ashtray (where I keep things like coins) is annoying to use and a bit of an eyesore and second, there are no cup holders.

inb4 "It's a driver's car it doesn't need cup holders!!!11!one1"
I like going through drive-throughs, I wanted a cup holder.

This project attempts to remedy both problems. It comes in two parts: the drop-in replacement "plug" for the OEM ashtray and the cup holder attachment. The cup holder slides into the ashtray plug when you need/want its functionality, and slides out to be stored in the door pocket when it's not needed. The cup holder hole is sized to nicely fit the small-sized drink cups at a few of my favorite fast food joints. You may have to adjust the hole diameter in FreeCAD to make it work for you.

I know it works on the 1987 Porsche 924S, but I can't confirm its functionality on cars I don't own. I think it would work on all of the 924/944 family, but I'm not totally sure. If you have one of those cars, let me know in the comments if/how it works!

Attached are the two components you need, plus the FreeCAD files for both the standard parts and a few options. 924ashtraypocket.fcstd is the plug without cup holding functionality, and 924ashtrayblank.fcstd is a blank plug for you to modify or use however you want.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print the plug with supports so it doesn't screw up the overhangs. The cup holder doesn't need them. I suggest an infill of 25%, but that and the resolution are up to you.

Finishing

I designed the cup holder so that the block would need to be sanded smooth. If I were to do it again, I would probably shrink the block a bit just to remove this step. As it was, I had to spend about 10 minutes with the palm sander getting it to slide well. This resulted in a very nice finish, but was definitely a bit of a hassle.

Installation

The OEM ashtray pulls out with a bit of force (don't worry, it's designed to be removable) and my replacement plug snaps in place without much trouble. Be sure to orient it such that the deeper cup holder pocket is towards the passenger side. When you want to use the cup holder, it slides in and hangs into the passenger seat, and your cup slides into the hole. If you have a passenger, cup holding is their job so I didn't worry about that too much.

Hi, this is my design for a Z-Axis opto sensor mount for the Orca 0.3. It is much more secure than the cable tie method, and follows on from my X-Axis Opto Mount. (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14155). The parts position can be adjusted easily, just slacken off the nut and bolt, move it to where you want it, and tighten back up. v2 - uses method similar to orca 0.40. One bolt adjusts, the other bolt and the 8mm bar guides. The spacers are used to tighten the bolts with nuts to stop them moving. I am using extruder springs and they seem to work well. The bolts are M4x40 cap heads. The picture is different to the current stl, i've modified it since fitting the one in the picture.

Print one of the z-opto mount.stl, drill out the holes to fit, push the sensor into the part, use an M3x20 nut and bolt to secure the opto sensor, and an M4x25 nut and bolt to secure the part to the smooth z-axis rod.
The opto-flag shouldn't need adjusting.
v2 - Will require cutting two new holes in the aluminium plate. The way I did this was to remove the bar clamp, place the part over the 8mm rod, and use it as a template to drill the holes. Only thing to be careful of is that the part is roughly in the right orientation before drilling.

description.text:
A lens mounted phone holder which utilises the level in your smart phone to set your camera perfectly level to your shoot surface.

Note: this is designed for shooting down from the ceiling only!

Camera: Any Canon EF mount camera
Phone: Designed for the LG G4 but will work with any phone that has a level front surface and is no wider than 77mm
App: Currently using an app called Bubble, designed by Ben Zibble (www.ktk.bz) and available for free at the Google Play Store. But any level app will work, as long as it has a calibrate option.

Instructions:

  1. Attach the device to the camera.
  2. Mount the camera to the ceiling, preferably with a geared head as pictured. The mount should be very solid to prevent any wobble.
  3. Open the app, go to options -> calibrate. Place the phone on your shoot surface and wait 5 seconds.
  4. Take the phone (being careful to maintain the same orientation) and slide into the device.
  5. Adjust the camera as needed.
  6. Bingo! Your camera is now perfectly level to your shoot surface.

I can make versions for different lens mounts & phones, just ask :)

Working files are also available at Onshape:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/1db3491898836f6ff3b98751

description.text:
Stylish, small, and cost effective was the main goal of these 22mm and 30mm Tank/RDA stands. They keep your Tank/RDA upright for display, organization, or storage purposes so the nasty leak that occurs from juice buildup, doesn't leave sticky little rings all over your table as well as keeping that ever so fragile glass on tanks nice and unbroken. The 510 hole is just large enough to fit a 510 without screwing but not so large that they would fall off when picking up the RDA or tank.

Print time at 15-20% is about 10-15mins.

24 of these stands takes about 3 1/2 hours.

description.text: Handle bar electronic switch enclosure was designed to mount over the (29mm diameter) handle bar grip on a Honda 4 wheeler and is used to turn a pull behind sprayer on and off. It uses a 16 Amp rocker switch I picked up at the Hardware store (Servalite 780704U Mini Rocker Switch SPST ON-OFF 16A, 12VDC). I also picked up 2 Phillips pan head # 8 x 1 1/2" long Stainless Steel screws used to fasten the mount to the handle bar grip...switch needs to be easy to operate and there is no room to mount to the bars inward from the grip so I made it as narrow as possible to limit the amount of the grip it covers...still plenty of room for most hands and it doesn't interfere with the other controls. The wires need to be soldered on to the switch terminals which will be trimmed to fit inside the enclosure and routed out through the angled hole in the side.

author: hoonchiat

description.text:
This is a filament dispenser for dry box, for people who need better airtight for their filaments. You need more materials to assemble this:

  • 2mm(inside)×4mm(outside) Teflon tube,
  • 4mm(inside)×6mm(outside)×5~6mm silicone tube,

maybe an 8mm×10mm×1~2mm silicone ring could provide extra airtight but I found this part is almost not needed. Also we have a closed part for unused dispensers.

You need to drill an 8mm hole on your dry box, and need no extra screws. This assembly do this itself.

05-02-2017 updated:

Models remaked. Now all holes and threads are more tightly (and tuning it with the XY compensation feature in your slicer software is recommended).

And all models are well-formed now.

author: hoonchiat

description.text:
I made this for my wife to keep her thread bobbins in order.
It has a divided pen holder area in the center.
I added four 624 bearings underneath to let it spin. If you print this i'd love to hear about it. UPDATE:
I added the .blend file for anyone who wants to play around.

Print.
Printed ok on my rep-rap with 0% infill, will go with >20% next time as some of the edges fell in a bit. Optional:
Install 4 624 bearings with M4x20mm screws. I recommend rubber bands or slices of tubing to act as tires.

comments.text: I had to do a quick filament change mid-print. At 60mm/s this was a rather long print, it took me around 6-7 hours. Looks great though!
comments.author: orias

comments.text: very nice! It's definitely a big print, over-nighter.  You made the swap in a good spot i think, im yet to give that a try.  Hope you like it, let me know if it you find any short comings in the design

description.text:
This is a "wobble" sprinkler with 1/2" bsp thread to suit many commercial risers and bases. Add an o-ring to the groove above the thread for a water tight seal.

The top oscillates in a wobble motion to distribute the water in all directions.

Just turn on the tap, give it a light tap or shake the hose to start it oscillating. Once it starts oscillating it never stops until you turn the tap off.

https://youtu.be/UW8JECZUFnM

Customizable V-Block for holding cylindrical parts. I designed this assembly using OpenSCAD as I wanted to try making parametric assemblies.

Disclaimer: Do not use this part for heavy machining. There's a reason these are made out of steel!

EDIT: I have now added an option called clampAngle. This will allow you to specify the angle of the clamping nut and bolt. By specifying clampAngle = 0 this will allow you to clamp round stock. Specifying clampAngle = 45 will allow for clamping of rectangular materials.

Using the customizer app you can easily change the dimensions of the v-block, the clamp to hold parts and adjust the nut and bolt used to clamp your parts.

For this model I used a 5/16-18UNC bolt and nut for the V-Block Clamp. The bolt that I used is 50mm long. Initially only 25mm of the bolt was threaded so I used a 5/16-18 die to thread the entire bolt shank.

Below are the dimensions used to create the show parts:

//V Block Dimensions
//Total V Block Length
Length = 75;
//V Block Height
Height = 50;
//V Block Width
Width = 50;
//Width of v Groove
vGrooveWidth = 40;
//v Groove notch depth
vNotchDepth = 2;
//v Groove notch width
vNotchWidth = 2;

//Notches in side of v block to allow for the attachment of v block clamp
sideDepth = 10;
sideWidth = 10;
//Tolerance of side notches to ensure good fit between clamp and v block
clampSideTolerance = 0.1;

//V Block Clamp Dimensions
//Thickness of Clamp
clampThickness = 10;
//Width of Clamp
clampWidth = Length*0.25;
//Height of Clamp above v block
clampHeight = 35;

//Dimensions of nut/ bolt support on top of v block clamp
//Thickness of Nut support
clampNutSupportThickness = 15;
//Width of nut Support
clampNutSupportWidth = 20;

//Dimensions of Nut and Bolt for securing parts in V block
//Diameter of bolt
boltDiameter = 8.25;
boltLength = 50;

//Width of nut- measure corner to corner distance on nut
nutWidth = 14.75;
//Nut thickness- measure thickness of nut
nutThickness = 7.0;

//Diameter of Bolt Knob
boltKnobDiameter = 20;
//Height of Bolt Knob;
boltKnobLength = 20;
//Number of knurls around Knob Diameter
boltKnobKnurlNum = 15;
//Depth of knurls
boltKnobKnurlDepth = 1;
//Width of knurls
boltKnobKnurlWidth = 1;
//Angle of knurling
boltKnobKnurlAngle = 100;

title: Another HBP Wire Guide

description.text:
This Heated Build Platform (HBP) wire guide is a derivative of Jetty's HBP Wire Guide (Thing 14687), http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14687 This derivative has two differences from its ancestor:
  • The wires do not need to be disconnected in order to put this guide into use, and
  • This guide can be bolted to the horizontal, wooden platform of the HBP -- it does not need a vertical cross member to bolt onto which is a good thing as not all build platforms have convenient cross members).
    • Note that once put into service, the retaining ring becomes a fully encompassing ring from which the wires cannot escape: the slots which admit the wires into each half of the ring are not aligned. Once the two halves are bonded together, the ring fully encloses the wires.

• Print the part.
  • Locate and mark any desired holes to be drilled -- you can use a M3 bolt running horizontally through a vertical cross member (Jetty's original design) or a vertical M3 bolt running through the horizontal wooden platform.
  • Drill the hole(s).
  • Slip each part around the wires.
  • Meld the two halves together using acetone or other solvent or glue them using a glue.
  • Slide the guide onto the build platform.
  • Bolt down with a M3 bolt and nut (you may need to use pliers to squeeze the nut into its hole in the guide if using a vertical bolt through the horizontal platform).

title: Small Desktop Vise
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This was modeled in the style of a mini toolmakers vise. Very useful for holding small parts for gluing, soldering, etc. The rear jaw slides on a dovetail in the base. The screw threads are an approximation of an ACME thread which should work smoothly once you get it broken-in.
It WILL be quite tight when you first try to run the screw in. I found that if you work it slowly, running the screw in a little bit more each time after backing it out, it will eventually seat and the screw will be easy to turn with no backlash. Take your time and don't try to force it too fast.

My objective with this model was to make it as easy to print as possible and to minimize the number of parts. The only extra parts required for assembly are 4x M3x20 cap-screws to fasten the screw block to the base. I tapped the screw holes in the screw block with an M3 tap, but you can probably force the screws to create their own threads if you don't have a tap. Test run to seat the the screws into the screw block first before assembling to the base.

The ball on the end of the screw shaft is a press fit into the pocket on the rear jaw. It should pop right in with a moderate amount of force. If your rear jaw is dragging (fits to tight) it may pop out when retracting. Overall length of the base of the vice is 116mm. Maximum jaw opening is approx 61mm.

PLA is likely the best material because it is stronger and more rigid than ABS. I used Hatchbox PLA, which tends to be less brittle than most other brands I've used. It is also much less prone to warping than ABS - which could be an issue when printing the base.

Printer:

Custom built Kossel 2020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100-150 micron for the threaded parts

Infill:

50% or more for the screw recommended

Notes:

Print the threaded parts at higher resolution with lots of cooling.
The parts are saved in the best orientation for printing. No need to flip anything.
No supports needed. The 4x holes for the M3 capscrews are tapered at the bottom of the counterbore to eliminate the need for support and to give a nice clean hole.
No gluing is required. Use 4x M3x20 capscrews to attach the screwblock to the base. The screwblock has a wedge on the front to take the axial load off of the screws when the vise is tightened.

DesignSpark Mechanical

author: KDan

description.text: OpenScad model of Irregular Frustum

Behold! The Type II Gunship!

Okay not exactly a gunship, but to the best that my inexperienced mind could create. This was actually one of my first models created in Sketchup that was designed specifically for 3D printing. A year after constructing and printing this I found the original CAD file in an old hard drive. I have updated the model to correct any errors that I know now to exist, based on the year-plus of experience I've gained since creating this. To add back to the model, I have incorporated all of my tricks and design philosophies into the file retroactively, and have now made it available for the public.

Inspired by the Avengers Quinjet and the UH-60 Black Hawk, this gunship is a fun desk model or a present for the young aspiring engineer. Attach the rocket pods to the fuselage mounts and chase your neighbors down the street! I will add additional "weaponry" as time goes on. Any questions or concerns let me know!

title: Blade Inductrix FPV Camera Mount - Tiny Whoop

description.text:
This is a Camera/VTX mount for the Blade Inductrix. It fits the ever popular Quanum/HK/Banggood Micro Camera/vtx combo. Weighs in at ~0.85g when printed with TPU, holds the camera securely and eliminates the chance of tearing a SMD component of the board with aggressive double sided tapes.

20 degree mount Works well with the 1.8 lense on these cameras.

All stock hardware is used, super simple installation. Just remove the front, and 2 side Flight Controller Screws, press them into the mount, and reassemble. Slip the cameras power wires through the hole in the mount, and seat the camera in the mount. Solder your power wires to the Battery input pads and your ready to fly.

UPDATE: Added 0 and 10 degree mounts in a lite configuration, also added a Lite 20 degree. Go Whoop it up!

comments.text: Got the part to work, in the Form 2 SLA you get better results if you print the part at an angle, they require it to be printed with supports also, so you .  Only issue was the power wires on my camera (FX798T).  The solder pads are in the same place but the wires were soldered coming straight out the back instead of the side and there's a little blob of black silicon on them.  So to get the camera to fit in I had to cut a slot on the back of the mount about 2mm wide starting right at the corner.  dremel out a couple of mm slot in the back of the mount so the camera could slide in.  The mount might be more universal if you just cut about 2mm out of both sides of the back left corner.

title: E3D Lowrider Mount for Rostock Max V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the first release of my "Lowrider" E3D mount for the Rostock Max v2. Easy to print and lightweight, just attach a set of SeeMeCNC ball joints and go...

http://www.seemecnc.com/collections/parts-accessories/products/replacement-ball-joints

I printed this in Taulman Alloy 910. If you have a Rostock Max, you already have a heated bed and the ability to print up to 240c, so give this stuff a try.

The holes in the effector plate are sized to snugly fit a mini-DIN socket. I'm about to experiment with using a mini-DIN connector and cable so that I can quickly and easily connect and disconnect my hot end.

More information later...

title: Wanhao Di3/Maker Select LED stage lighting

description.text:
The steel frame edges on these printers make an excellent mounting location for LED strips.

These mounts are low profile, positioning the strip in front of the frame.

They are designed for 10mm, 30/meter, non-addressable, IP65 waterproof, 12v, 5050 style strips. These strips have a silicone overlay that forms an arched top surface. They are also cuttable into 3 LED (50mm) segments.

The long parts are designed to fit a single segment. led_rail.stl is a middle part and is onmidirectional. The led_end_rail_?.stl parts are directional, and have a closed end to conceal the end of the strip.

The led_z_spacer_?.stl parts lift the side strips up to put the lowest LED just above the bed surface. They also have a gap that allows the wire to be inserted and a channel that wraps the wire around the frame for concealment. The tab on top fits into the slot on the long parts to conceal the wired end of the strip.

The parts have a strong grip on the frame so they won't fall off. The LED strip fits snug in the channel (leave the backing paper on). If your print has any pimples in the channel, they'll need to be shaved off.

As shown I have 4 LED segments on each side and 5 across the top for a total of 39 LEDs.

Use the latest revision of each file.

This completes stage 1 of this Thing.

TODO:

  • Modify the relevant parts from AzzA's Z Braces to add positionable light bars at the front and rear of the bed frame
  • Add a variant of led_rail.stl that can hold a filament filter in some way
  • Design a control box to allow each strip to be turned on individially, likely with a dimmer circuit
  • Modify the Diiicooler to place LEDs around its perimeter

EDIT 16 May 2016: Added a rendering of the work in progress concept for the "foot lights" apparatus. Will probably reuse most of the same parts for the back lights, still need to figure out how to position around the bed cable bundle.

EDIT 25 May 2016: Added first revision with files marked as rev001, and pictures showing a completed stage 1 install. The X and Z spacers go with strip segments oriented along that axis, so the Z spacers are for the sides, and X spacers for the top. There are now two versions of the Z spacers, low and high; these are meant to coincide with the mounting position of the Z endstop.

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with periemeter thickness 1.2mm on a .4mm nozzle (3 shells), which makes the infill mostly irrelevant. I also use 1.2mm top/bottom thickness.

Installation and wiring

These can be powered directly from the power supply inside the control box or on their own 12v wall wart. A full installation using 19 strip segments will draw approximately 1.14A at 12 volts.

For side and top rails, solder on a pigtail at least 8" long, this makes routing the wires around the Z rods easier. For the top rail, if you run the wiring on the left side of the printer, make sure to route it in such a way that it doesn't interfere with the Z endstop switch.

Slide the wires through the slot on the outward face of the spacer and thread the LED strip through your rail segments one at a time. Once all the pieces are on the strip they are ready for install. Slide the piece at the wired end onto the frame at an angle so that the strip leads away from the frame. Get the next piece slightly onto the edge, then push the first piece into position along with the adjacent end of the next piece. Repeat until done.

The side rails require extra care because of the tabs atop the Z spacers. Follow the procedure above starting with the second piece (just above the spacer), making sure the spacer is sitting on the Z motor mount and slightly onto the frame edge. Push the second piece into place, then the spacer, and continue with the third piece.

One of each X spacer and five rail segments is a fairly tight fit across the top of the gantry, you'll want to get the pieces as close to each other as possible.

Modelled in Blender using digital calipers for measurements. Went through 10 iterations getting the LED channel profile fit correct, and 3 more revisions for practical considerations.

All parts have been checked using Blender's 3d Printing Toolshelf add-on, so they are ready for slicing.
